review.title: Coalition-based Planning of Military Operations: Adversarial Reasoning Algorithms in an Integrated Decision Aid
review.abstract: Use of knowledge-based planning tools can help alleviate the challenges of planning a complex operation by a coalition of diverse parties in an adversarial environment. We explore these challenges and potential contributions of knowledge-based tools using as an example the CADET system, a knowledge-based tool capable of producing automatically (or with human guidance) battle plans with realistic degree of detail and complexity. In ongoing experiments, it compared favorably with human planners. Interleaved planning, scheduling, routing, attrition and consumption processes comprise the computational approach of this tool. From the coalition operations perspective, such tools offer an important aid in rapid synchronization of assets and actions of heterogeneous assets belonging to multiple organizations, potentially with distinct doctrine and rules of engagement. In this paper, we discuss the functionality of the tool, provide a brief overview of the technical approach and experimental results, and outline the potential value of such tools.

metadata.title: Coalition-based Planning of Military Operations: Adversarial Reasoning Algorithms in an Integrated Decision Aid

sections.text: We examine these challenges and potential contributions of knowledge-based tools using the example of the CADET system, a knowledge-based tool capable of automatically (or under human guidance) generating battle plans with realistic levels of detail and complexity. In ongoing experiments, it has been compared with human planners. Intertwined planning, scheduling, routing, exhaustion and consumption procedures form the computational approach of this tool. From the perspective of coalition operations, such tools provide important assistance in rapidly synchronizing assets and actions of heterogeneous assets belonging to multiple organizations, potentially with different doctrines and rules of engagement. In this paper, we discuss the functionality of the tool, give a brief overview of the technical approach and experimental results, and outline the potential value of such tools for coalition operations.

sections.heading: 2. Challenges and Capabilities
sections.text: A planning tool for coalition warfare must provide numerous capabilities to address a number of key challenges. Such capabilities fall into several broad categories: asset and task modeling Hostile environment Coordination of team efforts Autonomous ActionIn this section, we examine some examples of such capabilities and their possible relationships to coalition operations from a functional, domain-oriented perspective.

sections.heading: Modeling of assets and tasks
sections.text: As the modelling progressed, we captured the variations caused by a variety of different aspects of the employment cycle. For example, work with the Battle Command Battle Lab-Huachuca was able to perform a detailed breakdown of the sub-tasks involved in the restoration, take-off and positioning of a drone, and the possibility of simultaneous assignment was considered, with reconnaissance along the intrusion / exit route. The impact of UAV use on ground manoeuvres was greater than initially anticipated.

sections.heading: Adversarial environment
sections.text: Assumptions and expectations regarding the enemy are particularly challenging in a coalition where the doctrine of multi-nation staff officers can vary significantly and the political and strategic objectives of the participating nations can be at odds with each other (Riscassi 1993). Manual war games typically describe the enemy in a template, literally a standard tactical formation adapted to a specific terrain in a particular situation. Thus, the aim is to model the enemy over time and move it along the approach paths toward the friendly force. In practice, there are several aspects to considering how the enemy affects friendly actions. In particular, any action taken by one of the two combatants is likely to trigger an adversary's reaction and it may be possible to negate the response with the corresponding countermeasures. In addition, a fast, reliable conflict resolution model (CRM) is required to determine the impact of each deployment on the combatant.

sections.heading: Action/reaction/counter-action
sections.text: Any action that is possible by friendly or enemy units warrants consideration of potential responses. This is complemented by further analysis to determine whether there is a countermeasure that can be used to minimize the impact of the response or completely negate its impact.Figure 3 CADET estimates personnel and weapons systems that mimic the assessments carried out by Army experts. sections.heading: Conflict Resolution Modeling (CRM)
sections.text: Although the Dupuy (1990) approach offers many advantages for use in a system such as CADET, with the modest data requirements one of them, we found that it produced results that did not match users "expectations. After consulting expert panels of military officers, both active duty and retired, we modified the equations and coefficients provided in Dupuy (1990) to match the expertise and experience of current practitioners (Kott, Ground and Langston, 1999). In a coalition planning process, it may be desirable to either select from a library of multiple models or rapidly modify an existing model to take into account the perspectives and experiences of coalition members (Elron et. al., 1999).

sections.heading: Coordinating timing and movement
sections.text: Coalition warfare exacerbates the need for careful, thoughtful coordination of the temporal and spatial aspects of all tasks within an operation. Field Manual 3-0, the US Army's key operational manual, states: "Detailed war games, planning and rehearsals help us develop a common understanding of the deployment plan and control measures (Field Manual 3-0)." CADET users can enter time relationships for high-level activities into a plan. Expert experts and user feedback provided us with important information on how a commander understands the temporal relationships between activities. For example, does an attack in an area begin when the unit begins to move into the designated area when the unit attacks the designated area, or when the unit enters the designated area? In CADET, this problem is solved by identifying what we call anchor points for each activity. If the user says that two specific activities should begin at the same time, he or she has a specific idea of which activities should begin at the same time.

sections.heading: Coordinating supporting relationships
sections.text: Common errors that occur in manual COA analysis include under-utilization of resources, the obligation of resources to provide support when resources are out of reach, and resource binding. Figure 5 CADET interactively works with the user to identify questionable activities, enabling the user to accept or correct resource binding when a more complete solution for verification and decision-making is available. CADET tracks the use of resources to allow users to know where resources are not being fully utilized, a capability that can be used to find places where resources could be deployed elsewhere. CADET considers the effective range of supporting resources, such as logistics facilities, to determine whether they are close enough to achieve the mission.

sections.heading: Operating in three dimensions
sections.text: In practice, human planners tend to focus exclusively on close combat, without taking due account of the full depth of the battlefield. Leaders lacking experience with U.S. Army attack helicopters, for example, tend to diminish or disregard their value. A deep attack usually leads to serious enemy attrition, but carries the risk of friendly losses. If Army attack helicopters are lost behind enemy lines, it requires a combat search and rescue (CSAR) mission. On the other hand, a deep attack could reduce the enemy's strength to the point where the enemy is forced to abandon the attack. Whenever assets are available, a deep attack should be considered. Coalition staff officers can use CADET's ability to analyze airstrikes to build air-weapon COAs, where air and ground resources can belong to different coalition members.

sections.heading: 3. Technical Approach
sections.text: Let's briefly look at how CADET addresses some of the implicit technical challenges in the above-mentioned capabilities; integrating planning and planning is accomplished through an algorithm for tightly intertwined incremental planning and planning; the design step results in an incremental set of tasks by applying domain-specific "expansion rules" to these activities in the current state of the plan that require hierarchical decomposition; the design step results in a time restriction of deployment (both lateral and vertical within the hierarchy); and plans the newly added activities according to available resources and time periods (Kott, 1992; Sadeh, 1996; Kott, Ground Budd, 2002); and the networking mechanism is also used to integrate creative steps of routing, mapping, and consumption estimation.

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Comparisons – CADET vs. Manual Approaches
sections.text: A recent experiment, one of several series (Rasch, Kott and Forbus, 2002; Kott, Ground and Budd, 2002), comprised five different scenarios and nine judges (active service members of the U.S. military, primarily Colonel and Lieutenant Colonel), the five scenarios were derived from several exercises conducted by the U.S. Army. The scenarios were all brigade-sized and offensive, but still differed in terrain, mixture of friendly forces, nature of opposing forces, and maneuvering system. For each scenario / COA, we were able to view the COA sketches assigned to each planning staff, and the synchronization matrices produced by each planning staff. Participants, experienced observers of many planning exercises, estimated that these are usually conducted by a team of 4-5 officers, over the period of 3-4 hours, amounting to about 16 person-hours per planning product.

referenceMentions.context: In a coalition context, the planning staff rarely has the benefits of extensive joint training, and comes into the process with significantly different sets of procedures, terminology, and doctrines (Riscassi, 1993).
Under the umbrella of the CPoF program, CADET was integrated with the FOX GA system (Hayes and Schlabach, 1998) to provide a more detailed planner, coupled with COA generation capability.

Assumptions and expectations regarding the enemy are particularly challenging in a coalition, where the doctrine of staff officers from multiple nations can differ significantly and the political and strategic aims of the participating nations may be at odds (Riscassi 1993).

Having involved expert panels of military officers, both active duty and retired, we modified the equations and coefficients provided in (Dupuy, 1990) to match the expertise and experience of current practitioners (Kott, Ground and Langston, 1999).

Although the approach of Dupuy (1990) offers many advantages for application in a system like CADET, the modest demands on the required data being one of them, we found that it produced results that were not in concert with those expected by the users.

In the context of coalition warfare, even more so than in single-nation warfare, guidance from the commander should often come in the form of his intent or the desired results (Keithly and Ferris, 1999).

With the coalition planning process taking longer than single-nation planning, which is already considered too slow, the ability to perform multiple, rapid iterations of computerized planning is very important (Riscassi, 1993).
(Kott and Corpac, 2007) Such breadth and complexity of a problem go well beyond the scope of CADET.
